image.caption: Image courtesy of Library of Congress

profileText: A Delegate from Massachusetts; born in Quincy, Norfolk County, Mass., January 12, 1737; pursued classical studies; was graduated from Harvard College in 1754; a selectman of Boston several terms; member of the provincial legislature 1766-1772; president of the Provincial Congress in 1774; Member of the Continental Congress 1775-1778 and served as President of the Congress from May 24, 1775, to October 1777; first signer of the Declaration of Independence; served as senior major general of Massachusetts Militia during the Revolutionary War; member of the Massachusetts constitutional convention in 1780; Governor of Massachusetts 1780-1785; was again elected President of the Continental Congress on November 23, 1785, but resigned May 29, 1786, not having served on account of illness; again Governor of Massachusetts from 1787 until his death in Quincy, Mass., October 8, 1793; interment in Old Granary Burying Ground, Boston, Mass.

researchRecord.name: 1774-1865, 0.6 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: The papers include transcripts, made by John Hancock and his secretary, of letters from George Washington, Philip Schuyler, and Benedict Arnold. There are also transcripts of letters made of letter by John Hancock while President of the Continental Congress. There is also John Hancock's original account with the United States, transcripts of a rough journal of the Continental Congress, and various letters.

researchRecord.name: 1775, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A broadside, signed by John Hancock as President of the United Colonies, for an order of appointment of Benjamin Pattee as Lieutenant in the 5th regiment.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1775, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A document signed by John Hancock, from December 26, 1775, in reference to the arrest of soldiers for small private debts.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1776, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A resolutions passed by the United Congress on December 20, 1776 signed by John Hancock. The resolution called for the appointment of commissioners to various European courts.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1777, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to Thomas Jefferson written on October 25, 1777.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1778, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to Richard Caswell written on February 16, 1778. John Hancock writes regarding a convention.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1779, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to David Jeffries written on June 25, 1779. John Hancock writes concerning his client, Miss Winslow.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1782, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to William Salisbury written on March 20, 1782.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1782, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A document signed by John Hancock, Governor of Massachusetts, dated May 3, 1782. The document appoints Ezekiel Price as a justice of the peace.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1782, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A Thanksgiving discourse from John Hancock, dated November 1782.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1787, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A proclamation signed by John Hancock dated September 29, 1787. The proclamation appoints William Blanchard to the rank of colonel.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1788, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A deed signed by John Hancock on May 20, 1788. The deed transfers some land to the executors of the will of John Erving.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: 1792, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to Elbridge Gerry and others, written on March 13, 1792.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts

researchRecord.name: In the Hancock Family Papers, 1747-1865, 3 boxes.
researchRecord.description: Other authors include John Hancock. An item list to the papers is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Hancock Family Papers II, 1744-1804, 2 boxes.
researchRecord.description: The papers include receipts related to Harvard College finances during John Hancock's tenure as Treasurer, and other letters written to him. An unpublished guide to the papers is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: 1758, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to General Whitmore from November 6-10, 1758.

researchRecord.name: 1783, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to Samuel Eliott written on November 17, 1783. John Hancock requests "an American Device upon Revolution principles" to be painted on the panel of the coach he has ordered, and tells Samuel Eliott of his intention to resign as governor.

researchRecord.name: 1774-1838, 9 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers include a letter from Captain James Scott to Colonel John Hancock, from 1774, reporting the safe arrival of the ship Hayley, and commenting on reaction to the Boston Tea Party in London. Another letter from William Lee to John Hancock, from 1779, concerns his movements and his plans for defending New York City and discussing the treatment of Tories in the area. There are also receipts for pew rent, postage, bridge tolls, and taxes, some pertaining to Torry Hancock.

recordLocation.name: Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library

researchRecord.name: 1765, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A lottery ticket signed by John Hancock for the June Boston Faneuil-Hall lottery.

researchRecord.name: 1775, 5 pages.
researchRecord.description: These letters are copies made by John Hancock of the sharp exchange of letters between George Washington and the British commander, General Thomas Gage, in August 1775 respecting the treatment of Americans held prisoner by the British..

researchRecord.name: 1776, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A note from John Hancock to his wife, Dolly, written around January 1776. The note accompanies a letter to Captain McPherson relating to the death of his son. John Hancock also writes of General Montgomery's death, and how this would have occurred during the assault on Quebec, December 31, 1775.

researchRecord.name: 1776, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: These two resolves by Congress from when John Hancock was President of the Continental Congress. The resolves include requests from November 19 for the Councils of Safety of Pennsylvania and Southern states to "lay up Magazines of military Stores, ammunition & Salt provisions." The verso of the document dates from November 21 and directs recruiting officers of each state "to enlist their Men either for the War, or three years, upon the respective Bounties offered by Congress..."

researchRecord.name: 1779, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to the Board of War of the State of Massachusetts Bay written on November 5, 1779. John Hancock requests delivery of clothing newly made for "the Carolina Negroes." The postscript of the letter reads "We are much in want of a Bell, the old one being destroy'd by the British, I wish your Honors could furnish one."

researchRecord.name: ca. 1781-1788, 7 pages.
researchRecord.description: Appointments of Aaron Wood as Justice of the Court of Commons Pleas in the County of Essex, signed by Governor John Hancock.

researchRecord.name: 1782, 2 pages.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to John Brown written on May 6, 1782. John Hancock, Governor of Massachusetts, requests reimbursement for his services as President of the Continental Congress. He writes "I want only to be made whole, I never Expected nor Desired to make Money by the Contest..."

researchRecord.name: 1776, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to James Athearn written on June 22, 1776. The letter introduces and recommends privateers and supporters of the patriot cause.

recordLocation.name: R Stanton Avery Special Collections Department

researchRecord.name: 1783, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to Mrs. Hancock written on September 30, 1783. John Hancock writes about various social calls and health concerns, and lists comestibles and other items sent to Mrs. Hancock.

recordLocation.name: R Stanton Avery Special Collections Department

researchRecord.name: 1776, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to the New York State Convention on behalf of the Continental Congress, requesting that the New Yorkers marshal their troops to meet the British forces.

researchRecord.name: 1791, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A receipt, dated July 7, 1791, from John Hancock (Boston) to Furness and Walley for payment of 12 pounds 10 shillings, for one quarter rent of his store.

recordLocation.name: H. H. Furness Memorial Library, Special Collections, Van Pelt Library

researchRecord.name: 1776, 1 page.
researchRecord.description: A document signed by John Hancock on July 22, 1776, consisting of three resolutions of Congress, concerning the exchange of prisoners, particularly Colonel Ethan Allen.

researchRecord.name: 1783, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to Jacob Sheafe written on October 18, 1783, introducing Major Segord of the cavalry. John Hancock mentions his son's recovery from smallpox.

researchRecord.name: 1758-1760, 3 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers contain drafts of letters from John Hancock to General Whitmore.

parentRecordLocation.name: State University of New York at Buffalo

researchRecord.name: 1758-1760, 4 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers contain drafts of letters from John Hancock to Colonel Wilmott.

researchRecord.name: 1760, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to Daniel Shea written on March 3, 1760.

parentRecordLocation.name: State University of New York at Buffalo

researchRecord.name: 1762, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: Correspondence from John Hancock.

parentRecordLocation.name: State University of New York at Buffalo

researchRecord.name: 1777, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to Robert Morris written on October 5, 1777. The letter is housed in the Lockwood Collection.

parentRecordLocation.name: State University of New York at Buffalo

researchRecord.name: In the Miscellaneous Manuscripts Collection, 1764, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A note from John Hancock to Joseph Jackson written on December 27, 1764.

researchRecord.name: 1788, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A document signed by John Hancock on March 26, 1788, appointing James Sullivan as justice to keep the peace.

researchRecord.name: 1791, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from John Hancock to Henry Knox written on March 24, 1791. John Hancock writes regarding sending 2 quintals of fish to be shipped from Boston to Philadelphia.
